title: New Medicus Healthcare Solutions White Paper Examines the U.S. Cardiologist Shortage
text:
WINDHAM, N.H. , Feb. 20, 2025 /PRNewswire/ -- The United States is projected to face a shortage of up to 8,650 cardiologists by 2037, raising serious concerns about access to cardiovascular care. To help healthcare leaders navigate the growing workforce challenge, Medicus Healthcare Solutions has released a new white paper titled An Inside Look at the Cardiology Workforce: Shortages, Demand, and Strategic Responses .
This in-depth report provides a comprehensive look into the cardiology workforce and the key factors driving demand. In addition, the white paper outlines actionable strategies to mitigate the impact of the cardiologist shortage and strengthen clinical staffing.
Key Insights Within the Report Include:
Workforce & Job Growth Projections Rural Disparities in Cardiovascular Care Rising Health Risks & Cardiology Demand Actionable Strategies for Solving the Cardiologist Shortage & More. "The rising prevalence of cardiovascular disease, combined with a growing shortage of cardiologists, presents a significant challenge for U.S. healthcare. Given the considerable clinical and financial value cardiologists bring to any health system, organizations that take a proactive approach to attracting and retaining cardiology talent will remain one step ahead of the competition. A strategic, multi-faceted, and accountable staffing partner would only further this type of competitive advantage in a challenging marketplace." - Steve Gable , Vice President of Sales
Click here to access the complete report, An Inside Look at the Cardiology Workforce: Shortages, Demand, and Strategic Responses .
About Medicus Healthcare Solutions Medicus Healthcare Solutions has been connecting physicians and advanced practice providers to medical groups, practices, health systems, hospitals, and other facilities throughout the United States since 2004. Since then, Medicus has expanded its services to include the Medicus Transition Program, an all-in-one approach to interim staffing and workforce stabilization; MedicusOne, a hybrid of vendor management and managed service provider system; resource management services, and consulting services. Through its proprietary solutions and methodologies, including mSolve, Medicus has built a reputation for its unique and highly personalized approach to physician staffing. With over 300 employees, Medicus Healthcare Solutions is one of the fastest-growing companies in the healthcare staffing industry. To learn more, go to www.medicushcs.com .
About the Medicus Transition Program The Medicus Transition Program is a project-based staffing solution that simplifies interim provider staffing for hospitals, physician groups, and other medical facilities. Specializing in long-term coverage for specialties with multiple FTE gaps, the Transition Program promotes shared accountability in sourcing, scheduling, and cost control, providing healthcare leaders with the flexibility to fill their staffing gaps quickly and efficiently.

title: Ministra del Trabajo dice que el incremento del salario mínimo permitirá mantener el poder adquisitivo | Gobierno | Economía | Portafolio
text:
Luego de que el Ministerio del Trabajo abriera espacios de diálogo con diferentes sectores, el Gobierno fijó el incremento salarial a partir de lo establecido en la Ley 278 de 1996,
La ministra de Trabajo, Gloria Inés Ramírez, señaló en un comunicado a la opinión pública, que "se realizaron 10 reuniones bilaterales entre el Gobierno, empresarios y centrales que hacen parte de la Comisión Permanente de concertación de políticas salariales y laborales a fin de buscar un acuerdo que permitiera la fijación concertada del salario mínimo del 2024".
(Únase mundo). Sin embargo, sin un acuerdo, "se procedió a la aplicación del inciso segundo del parágrafo del artículo octavo de la ley 278 de 1996", comentó la ministra.
Así, mediante un decreto, el Gobierno estableció " un incremento al salario mínimo aproximadamente del 12 %, es decir, que queda en 1'300.000 pesos es decir. Y un incremento al auxilio del transporte en 162 mil pesos, el cual corresponde aproximadamente a un 15%" .
Para la jefa de la cartera "estos incrementos con seguridad permitirán a las y a los colombianos mantener el poder adquisitivo de los salarios para el año 2024 , pues el propósito siempre atendió la obligación de fijar un incremento al salario mínimo teniendo en cuenta los criterios técnicos aportados por el Departamento Administrativo Nacional de Estadística, por el Banco de la República, por la Academia y las bases constitucionales y legales".
(Vea: Lo que subiría de precio con el nuevo salario mínimo para el 2024).
El Ministerio afirmó que el porcentaje tiene como objetivo favorecer la garantía de las condiciones económicas que promueven la calidad de vida digna para los trabajadores y sus familias. Salario mínimo iStock
Es importante resaltar que la Comisión permanente trabajó durante un mes para ir avanzando en un resultado. Así, el Ministerio registró cuatro reuniones formales de diálogo y partió dos reuniones de la Subcomisión de productividad y una reunión de la Subcomisión de empleo y empleabilidad.
Por otra parte, la ministra informó que "se desindexaron de 88 bienes. Productos que sin duda son fundamentales para la calidad de vida de las familias y trabajadores y que fueron consenso en la Comisión de Concertación".
Por último, Ramírez agradeció "la disposición que tuvieron los empresarios y los trabajadores con las centrales obreras para que efectivamente pudiésemos haber trabajado conjuntamente de manera alterna".
(Vea: Presidente Petro propone 'reformar la reforma tributaria' para elevar la productividad).

author: FOX 13 News
title: Governor Ron DeSantis says Hurricane Milton recovery efforts are picking up | FOX 13 Tampa Bay
text:
By FOX 13 News Staff Updated October 11, 2024 11:29am EDT Hurricane Milton FOX 13 News Share
Copy Link Email Facebook Twitter LinkedIn Reddit Press play above to watch FOX 13 News ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. - Governor Ron DeSantis says recovery efforts are picking up in the aftermath of Hurricane Milton in Florida .
DeSantis spoke Friday morning at a news conference in St. Petersburg , which saw extensive damage as Milton hit the state's Gulf coast late Wednesday and early Thursday.
"There's damage and there's a lot that's going to need to be done," DeSantis said. "We did not get the worst case scenario, but we did get hit and we're going to have to work to bounce back."
So far, at least eight deaths are being blamed on the storm, and that number could keep going up.
FOX partners with Red Cross for Hurricane Helene and Milton relief: How to help
Power outages still widespread DeSantis said about 2.4 million Floridians are still without power while 1.6 million accounts have been restored as of 9 a.m. Friday.
Officials with Duke Energy also spoke at the news conference, saying the utility expects to provide customers a timeline for restoration later on Friday.
Fuel concerns The governor said there is fuel ready to be deployed, but power issues at critical distribution sites are delaying deliveries, according to Port Tampa Bay officials.
Rescue efforts DeSantis said 1,600 people and 140 animals have been rescued through state and local collaborations. Rescue missions continue in several hard-hit areas.
Resources for impacted Floridians Florida's Assistance Hotline is open and accepting calls 24/7 with English, Spanish and Haitian-Creole speakers available at 1-800-342-3557.
